question.title: Pushing GridBagLayout-managed components to one side
question.body:
My pink label positioned right in the middle of the remaining horizontal space. I simply want them both to the left.

The layout put the pink label to the left of the right cell (which are made equal in width) â€” not to the left of the whole container, as I wanted to.

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JLabel;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.WindowConstants;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Container;
import java.awt.GridBagConstraints;
import java.awt.GridBagLayout;

public class GridBagLayoutDemo {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Container mainPanel = createMainPanel();
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("GridBagLayout Demo");
        frame.setContentPane(mainPanel);
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    private static Container createMainPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
        GridBagConstraints constraints = new GridBagConstraints();
        constraints.anchor = GridBagConstraints.WEST; // which, I figure, means LEFT in plain English
        constraints.weightx = 1;
        constraints.weighty = 1;
        constraints.fill = GridBagConstraints.VERTICAL;
        panel.add(createLabelOne(), constraints);
        panel.add(createLabelTwo(), constraints);
        return panel;
    }

    private static JLabel createLabelOne() {
        JLabel label = new JLabel("Test label 1");
        label.setOpaque(true);
        label.setBackground(Color.LIGHT_GRAY);
        return label;
    }

    private static JLabel createLabelTwo() {
        JLabel label = new JLabel("Test label 2");
        label.setOpaque(true);
        label.setBackground(Color.PINK);
        return label;
    }
}

I need the vertical fill, so I can't use FlowLayout or BoxLayout.

    private static Container createMainPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel();
        BoxLayout layout = new BoxLayout(panel, BoxLayout.X_AXIS);
        panel.setLayout(layout);
        panel.add(createLabelOne());
        panel.add(createLabelTwo());
        panel.add(Box.createGlue());
        return panel;
    }

Basically, I need to effectively combine the vertical fill on the first screenshot with the horizontal positioning on the second screenshot.

I am using Swing in Java 8.

answers.body:
Adding a filler component solves the problem, but looks stupid imo.

    private static Container createMainPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
        GridBagConstraints constraints = new GridBagConstraints();
        constraints.weightx = 0;
        constraints.weighty = 1;
        constraints.fill = GridBagConstraints.VERTICAL;
        panel.add(createLabelOne(), constraints);
        panel.add(createLabelTwo(), constraints);
        constraints.weightx = 1;
        panel.add(Box.createGlue(), constraints);
        return panel;
    }

Introduce a parent wrapper container.

You can have the parent:

private static Container createParentPanel() {
  JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
  panel.add(createChildPanel(), createParentConstrains());
  return panel;
}

private static GridBagConstraints createParentConstrains() {
  GridBagConstraints constraints = new GridBagConstraints();

  constraints.anchor = GridBagConstraints.FIRST_LINE_START;
  constraints.fill = GridBagConstraints.VERTICAL;
  constraints.weightx = 1;
  constraints.weighty = 1;

  return constraints;
  }

Then you have your children:

private static Container createChildPanel() {
  JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
  GridBagConstraints constraints = createChildConstraints();

  panel.add(createLabelOne(), constraints);
  panel.add(createLabelTwo(), constraints);

  return panel;
}

private static GridBagConstraints createChildConstraints() {
  GridBagConstraints constraints = new GridBagConstraints();
  constraints.anchor = GridBagConstraints.WEST;
  constraints.fill = GridBagConstraints.VERTICAL;
  constraints.weighty = 1;
  return constraints;
}

79693040.body: It is fine to do this.  There has to be something in that cell, and Swing is very good at optimizing components which do no painting.  You can add a blank JLabel or empty JPanel instead, if you prefer, but there is nothing at all wrong with using Box.createGlue here.
@VGR I'm adding a dummy component (from another layout API to boot) instead of using a layout to correctly position actual components
This is exactly the right way to handle it.  What looks stupid about it?
